question: Question_01_(d)
statement:
\emph{Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it
is true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a
counterexample.}

\textbf{(d)} If $f$ has a vertical asymptote at \emph{x} = 0, then is
reciprocal 1/$f$ has a vertical asymptote at \emph{x} = 0.
sols:
This statement is \textbf{false}.

As a counterexample, consider $f(x)$ = 1/\emph{x}. It has a
vertical asymptote at \emph{x} = 0, but its reciprocal 1/$f$ = \emph{x}
has no vertical asymptotes.
hints:
Try known examples of functions with vertical asymptotes at 0 and look
at their reciprocal functions. This should give you the intuition of
this question.

One can also look at this abstractly by recalling the definition of what
it means to have a vertical asymptote and how this would affect the
reciprocal function, but trying examples should be sufficient.
